entry.title: Listing all installed apt packages
entry.summary: 1. Use sudo apt list --installed to see all that is installed on your Linux system. It will give…
entry.content:
1. Use sudo apt list --installed   to see all that is installed on your Linux system. It will give you a rather large list.

2.Use sudo apt list --installed | less to make it scroll able, q to quit out of the scroll.   

3.If you want to search for a specific package or a keyword use sudo apt list --installed | grep -i keyword.

entry.title: Outputting file content in the terminal.
entry.summary: There are various ways to see what is inside a file inside the terminal. cat filename would output the contents…
entry.content:
There are various ways to see what is inside a file inside the terminal. 

cat filename would output the contents of a file. 

If you need to have a little more control over what and how it is being shown on the screen use 

less filename  would let you scroll through the contents of the file. To exit that use q.

more filename would output one page at a time.

entry.title: Changing directories in terminal
entry.summary: cd foldername /* changes to the folder specified cd .. /* goes up one directory cd \. /* takes you…
entry.content:
cd foldername /* changes to the folder specified
cd .. /* goes up one directory
cd \.  /* takes you back one directory
cd  /* takes you to home directory

entry.title: How to build the Linux Kernel
entry.summary: This build process is for Ubuntu/Debian Download the latest kernel from Linux kernel archives as tar. Once you have those…
entry.content:
This build process is for Ubuntu/Debian

Download the latest kernel from Linux kernel archives as tar. Once you have those files downloaded extract the files and open the file in terminal. 

First step of kernel building is to configure the kernel. There's multiple utilities you can use, for example 

make config  or make menuconfig

The first one is a command line input which can take a while to configure, the alternative is to have a terminal based gui, which is what the second command does. 

In this article I wont be going through the process of manually configuring the build. We will use the default configuration and that will generate a configuration file for the build process. 

Use make defconfig to set the default configuration. 

Once you have that you can run the make command to build the kernel. You might encounter problems while installing them.  Check this post for the packages that you might need to install.

entry.title: Errors or packages Installed during kernel build
entry.summary: Error: scripts/extract-cert.c:21:10: fatal error: openssl/bio.h: No such file or directory #include sudo apt-get install aptitude sudo aptitude install libssl-dev…
entry.content:
Error: scripts/extract-cert.c:21:10: fatal error: openssl/bio.h: No such file or directory #include 

 

sudo apt-get install aptitude

sudo aptitude install libssl-dev

 

Other errors in build processes 

sudo apt-get install libelf-dev

entry.summary: Hey I am Sam. I use this blog to write about things that are related to programming and other…
entry.content: Hey I am Sam. I use this blog to write about things that are related to programming and other technology related stuff.  Mostly they are just notes that are publicly available.

entry.title: make menuconfig
entry.summary: While trying to run the make menuconfig to configure the build of Linux Kernel I encountered some issues. Mainly that I…
entry.content:
While trying to run the make menuconfig to configure the build of Linux Kernel I encountered some issues. Mainly that I didn't have many of the packages installed. 

This is just a list of commands, i.e package names to install. It might differ based on what you already have installed on your computer. Its in the order the errors were thrown out saying something wasn't available in order to use make menuconfig

sudo apt-get install pkg-config

To install ncurses a sort of terminal gui. 

sudo apt-get install libncurses5-dev libncursesw5-dev

If flex not found

sudo apt-get install flex

If Bison not found

sudo apt-get install bison

I could run make menuconfig after installing those
